Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Use and Knowledge of Research-Based Instructional Strategies (RBIS) in Engineering Science Courses

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration:
This engineering education research project seeks to continue ongoing work to better understand the barriers to wide adoption of educational methods that have been proven to improve many aspects of student learning in engineering. The PIs plan a comprehensive survey of electrical and chemical engineering faculty; the project partners with the IEEE (electrical engineering) and AIChE (chemical engineering) professional societies to improve participation. If successful, this research project will help provide the faculty perspective on barriers to broad adoption of research-proven pedagogies.

The broader significance and importance of this project will be to understand, then ultimately lower, barrier to adoption of teaching techniques that have been proven to engage diverse audiences of engineering students. While successful at improving retention and engagement of students, including those from under-represented groups, these techniques have not spread widely, and researchers do not yet have a clear understanding of why.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This engineering education research project sought to better understand the barriers to wide adoption of educational methods that have been proven to improve many aspects of student learning in engineering. The investigators conducted a national survey of engineering instructors of introductory classes: 122 electrical engineering, 99 chemical engineering, and 166 statics instructors (primarily in mechanical and civil engineering). Then, they visited two different universities to interview instructors of the same types of courses as well as administrators to better understand the types of support engineering faculty receive for improving their teaching. 

The broader significance and importance of this project is better understanding of the pressures and decisions of engineering instructors about their teaching. Prior research demonstrates that many students leave engineering majors in the first two years and that they cite poor teaching as a major reason. The sophomore level courses this project focused on are particularly challenging for students because they cover large amounts of difficult technical material. However, other prior research shows that students learn better and are more motivated when they are actively engaged in their learning, for example by working on problems with peers rather than just listening to a lecture. The investigators' own prior research demonstrates that simply having the evidence of better teaching methods is not enough to convince engineering instructors to use them.

Specifically, this project gained several insights into how engineering instructors make decisions about their teaching. First, the data show that the problem of limited use of evidence-based teaching strategies is not about awareness. Most engineering instructors surveyed were aware of the teaching strategies. Many had even tried them. The biggest gap was between instructors who tried the strategies once but were not convinced to continue using them. The approaches can be very different from traditional teaching, and instructors and students may not be comfortable with them at first. This finding is important because the developers of these new teaching methods tend to focus on raising awareness rather than coaching instructors in using them, which may be a more effective strategy. 

Second, the survey supplied data on the sources of information and barriers reported by engineering instructors for their decisions to use (or not use) evidence-based teaching strategies. These results highlighted the importance of local networks and conversations with colleagues to encourage faculty members to try, persist, or just find out more about evidence-based instructional strategies. This finding is important because many engineering teaching reform initiatives are national rather than local, but local support and initiatives may be needed to effect change. 

Third, the survey and interview data shows that engineering instructors' beliefs about learning, specifically the importance of problem-solving and lectures, influences the amount of class time they spend on these activities. Although the importance of practicing solving problems was widely recognized by survey respondents, the interviews revealed that there are other barriers to instructors using class time for problem solving.
